KGLW.net Staff Notes: The setlist may be incomplete. Robot Stop, Muckraker and The River were confirmed by audio/video and the rest were reported by attendees. Although the band claimed on 2022-06-17 that they first debuted Robot Stop at Bonnaroo on 2015-06-12, the brief audio/video clip of Robot Stop from this performance appears to contradict this. We have chosen to include the song on the setlist despite the band's claim as additional audio/video evidence shows that the band were recording and rehearsing songs for Nonagon Infinity as early as February 2015, as well as Evil Death Roll and Gamma Knife being debuted during the other Gizzfest shows. There is also uncertainty as to whether all new songs have been properly identified, if the songs are in the correct order, and if a complete Head On/Pill was played or only the Pill section. If anyone has any additional information about this show or, ideally, a complete or conclusive recording please contact KGLW.net staff at setlists@kglw.net.

Gamma Knife, Robot Stop and Evil Death Roll were introduced as new songs and all contained alternate lyrics. Evil Death Roll contained a flute solo. After Evil Death Roll, Joey introduced Cavs as "John Henry Bonham". Joey ended the show with a shoutout to Unknown Mortal Orchestra.

Wah-Wah, Robot Stop and Evil Death Roll were introduced as new songs and all contained alternate lyrics. Before Robot Stop, Joey shouted out Australian Basketball player Matthew Dellavedova, who was playing for the Cleveland Cavaliers at the time. Before Muckraker, which was played by audience request, Cavs teased Dustbin Fletcher.

Am I In Heaven? contained Evil Death Roll teases. It's Got Old was performed as an audience request. Robot Stop was introduced with the working title “new new song” and contained alternate lyrics and Am I In Heaven? teases. Head On/Pill contained a flute solo from Stu, Am I In Heaven? teases and quotes and I'm In Your Mind and Cellophane teases.

Gamma Knife, Hot Water, Robot Stop & Evil Death Roll all contained alternate lyrics. The River was dedicated by Stu to "my man Wayne."  Muckraker was dedicated to "that guy over there." Am I In Heaven? contained Cellophane & Hot Water teases. Prior to the final Pill section, Joey shouted out sound tech Sam and Stu dedicated “this song and every song that we ever play ever” to Jason Galea.

This is the second show of the day following a semi-acoustic show featuring Ty Segall & Christian Peslak. Wah Wah and Robot Stop were introduced as a new songs and contained alternate lyrics. After The River, Stu and Joey passed out water and mentioned his fingers had pruned with sweat. Danger $$$ was played at the request of an audience member. Before Am I In Heaven?, Joey and Stu ask for another audience request, only to have Ambrose to interject, “you’ll have what your given.”  Between Heaven and Pill, Stu sprayed the audience with water.

Show Notes: The band walked out to The Nonagon Intro Theme. Head On/Pill contained an Am I in Heaven? jam with lyrics and a flute solo. Robot Stop, People Vultures and Evil Death Roll were introduced as a new songs. After People Vultures, a fan got on stage to crowd surf and was coaxed by Joey. After the River, a fan requests Work This Time and Stu teases it. Thank you to Peter Deckers for the video and Stef Van Alsenoy for the Audio.

Trapdoor was dedicated to John Sulta. After The River, Stu shouted out the other bands playing that day at Levitation. Cut Throat Boogie was introduced as "a song from way back when, when I [Ambrose] was just 16". This show was released through the Official Bootlegger program as Live at Levitation ‘16.

Before Head On/Pill, Stu asked the crowd "how about this one?" and teased the intro to Bone. The traditional transition from Cellophane > I'm In Your Mind Fuzz did not occur due to Stu noticing someone being kicked out for crowdsurfing, which prompted him to pause the song and ask for them to be let back in, and then told the crowd to look out for each other. Stu called out Evil Death Roll before The River, which was introduced as a jazz song, implying it was listed before The River on the setlist. Head On/Pill featured Stu on flute. Thank you to Marty Loving for the full recording of this show.

Before Robot Stop, Stu said that they would be "trying something they had never really done before", referring to this being the first time the band performed the full Robot Stop through People-Vultures suite. After Trapdoor, Stu told the crowd that this was their first time in Indianapolis and asked if they had seen openers Chives and The Murlocs. Before Evil Death Roll, an audience member yelled out “you gotta play Road Train!” which Stu proceeded to tease. Thank you to ironchef for the full recording of this show.

After the Mind Fuzz suite, Stu told the crowd it was Cookie's 25th birthday, followed by the band singing “Happy Birthday to You” and Stu getting him to crowd surf for the first time. Before The River, an audience member requested Footy Footy, to which Joey asked if they even know what Australian football is. Head On/Pill contained Am I In Heaven? teases and quotes. After Trapdoor, Joey commented that the venue "smells like [his] dad's breath, which is good!". After I'm In Your Mind Fuzz, Stu briefly teased Stressin'. Head On/Pill contained Robot Stop, Evil Death Roll, Hot Water and Big Fig Wasp teases, Cellophane and Am I In Heaven? teases and quotes and a flute solo. Thank you Michael Zelner for the full recording of this show.

Overkill (Motörhead) played as the band came on stage. During I'm Not In Your Mind, a camera recording the band fell over and Joey had to alert an audience member to bring it to a crew member. Head On/Pill featured Stu on flute and contained Robot Stop, Hot Water, Sea of Trees and Rattlesnake teases, as well as Cellophane and Am I In Heaven? teases and quotes. This show was recorded and released as the Live in San Francisco '16 album and concert film.

Willoughby's Beach was played for the first time known since 2015-06-27 (106 show gap). Wah Wah was played for the first time known since 2015-08-28 (83 show gap). The Lord of Lightning and The Balrog were introduced as new songs. Invisible Face was incomplete. The River contained Parts I, II, and IIIWah Wah contained The River teases. Thank you to Travis Kier for the complete recording

Between I’m In Your Mind Fuzz and Evil Death Roll Stu thanked the crowd in Portuguese. Invisible Face was incomplete. Only Part 1 of the The River was played. Wah-Wah contained quotes from The River. High Voltage (AC/DC) played before and as the band walked on stage for the first set. All Is Known was introduced as a new song and contained alternate lyrics. During Billabong Valley, the guitar strap fell off the Flying Microtonal Banana while Ambrose was using it, with Joey jokingly telling Stu afterwards that his guitar was broken and that Ambrose should "stick to the blues harp". NOBODY'S BABY (Sheer Mag) played before and as the band walked on stage for the second set. Before Gamma Knife, the crowd started chanting for Stu to do a "shoey", to which he told them to "be reasonable" and that he was "too old for that". The Balrog was introduced as a new song. Am I In Heaven? contained a medley of teases and quotes including Alter Me, Cellophane, Rattlesnake, Hot Water, Head On/Pill and The River as well as a Sea of Trees jam with lyrics. This performance was filmed in 360-degree video and released as "King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard - 360° Full Concert" on the Banalarama YouTube channel, featuring audio mixed by Stu
Webcast live by Pitchfork. Night one was performed in the grand ballroom.
Sea Of Trees was played for the first time known since 2014-10-24. (217 show gap)

This show featured the debut of Vomit Coffin. Following Rattlesnake, the band wished a happy birthday to Eric. Am I In Heaven? contained teases and quotes of Cellophane, The River, Head On/Pill, I'm In Your Mind, Sea of Trees, Rattlesnake, and Robot Stop. Prior to the show, Stu accidentally posted a link containing demos for all of Polygondwanaland to the Facebook fan page under the name “Blinky Bill”. Although removed shortly after, someone was able to download the first two demos causing Stu to message them claiming he was a fan named Han-Tyumi and asked for the demos not to be reposted. data.showtitle: This Is Not A Love Song Festival

data.shownotes: During final song Stu crowd surfed out of the venue and into the sea, while the band continued to play.
Poster by Olya Dyer, limited to 100
John Peel set
Am I In Heaven? contained People Vultures, Cut Throat Boogie, Rattlesnake, Alter Me, Robot Stop, Cellophane, I'm In Your Mind, Head On/Pill, and Float Along - Fill Your Lungs teases and quotes.

Cut Throat Boogie was played for the first time known since 2016-05-13. (148 show gap) Danger $$$ was played for the first time known since 2016-05-14. (146 show gap) KGLW.net Staff Notes: The setlist for this show is believed to be complete. The songs were confirmed through contemporaneous discussions through various social media, but any additional setlist notations that require audio confirmation (guest appearances, segues, quotes or teases) may be incomplete. If anyone has any further information or, ideally, a complete or conclusive recording please contact KGLW.net staff at setlist@kglw.net.

This was the band's first show in Ireland, and took place at the historic Olympia Theatre (later known as 3Olympia Theatre for sponsorship purposes). The band was supported by Mild High Club. Alex Brettin from Mild High Club sat in during King Gizzard's set for D-Day and The Book. God Is In The Rhythm was played for the first time known since 2015-06-24. (241 show gap)

This show featured the debut of Beginner's Luck. Stu sat in on flute with opener Mild High Club on Sketches of Brunswick East II. Alex Brettin from Mild High Club played guitar for D-Day and The Book. Malcolm Brown (formerly of Whitney) played keyboard on Beginner's Luck.

This show featured the debut of Rock N’ Roll. On The Road Again (Rockets) played as the band came on stage. The vocal intro to Nuclear Fusion was not performed. Han-Tyumi, The Confused Cyborg contained alternate lyrics and Stu on flute. Before Rock N’ Roll, Joey had to gently kick a fan off the stage. Stu later mentioned that they were recording the show that night, and that the unreleased song (Rock N’ Roll) was "kinda new". A pro-shot video of The Fourth Colour was released on the Flightless Records YouTube channel. The Fourth Colour contained a tuning session outro with a droning noise playing in the background, and eventually Cellophane teases. Robot Stop contained Master of the Universe (Hawkwind) teases and quotes, and a Hot Water tease. Malcolm Brown (formerly of Whitney) played keyboard on Beginner's Luck. Stu sat in on flute with opener Mild High Club on Sketches of Brunswick East II.
King Khan performed improvised vocals over God Is In The Rhythm

Before Digital Black, Stu asked the crowd if anyone was at the band's previous show in Atlanta, followed by Cavs briefly teasing Moby Dick. data.jamchart_notes: This show opening, first acoustic, first post-covid version of The River is a major indication of the direction the band was moving in at the time. Unlike any previous version, the first jam section showcases a looser, inspired and creatively liberated band, as it opens up into fun interplay between all members of the band before simmering down to a whisper. The outro jam features strong playing from all and great variations on the composed outro licks with a particularly jazzy flair.
data.shownotes: This show was a fully acoustic warmup gig for acoustic night of the Princess Theatre residency and featured the debut of Most of What I Like. It's Got Old was played for the first time since 2015-09-13. (354 show gap) Sleepwalker was played for the first time since 2016-02-28. (325 show gap) Most Of What I Like contained “Praise You” (Fatboy Slim) teases. The intro to Sense contained “Come On” (The Notorious B.I.G.) quotes. Prior to Slow Jam 1 opening band The Bush was shouted out and mention was made that Ambrose's sister Edith is in the band. The song itself contained a Her and I (Slow Jam 2) tease.

data.jamchart_notes: The main jam segment is exceptional on all fronts, from Amby’s deft piano and harmonica playing, to the focused guitar work from Stu, Joey, and Cook exploring multiple themes, to the rhythm section’s pocketed groove. The rest of the song is also quite strong; every section is performed with gusto, from the first section’s great banter and interplay, to the third section’s deliberate fade, to the outro’s swagger of a band at its prime. A definite contender for the title of GOAT River.
data.shownotes: This was the Acoustic Night show of the Princess Theatre residency, the first of five planned shows, each featuring a different specific genre and preannounced songs. The Bitter Boogie was dedicated to “the last two years.” Most Of What I Like contained Praise You (Fatboy Slim) teases. Her and I contained Slow Jam 1 quotes. This show was released through the Official Bootlegger program as Live in Brisbane '21. Poster By Jason Galea Edition of 200

This show featured the debut of Blame It On the Weather. I’m Not In Your Mind contained Rattlesnake teases and Boogieman Sam quotes. Gaia featured a drum solo by Cavs. Mystery Jack was introduced as the oldest song that would be played that night, followed by a tease of “Frankenstein” (Edgar Winter Group). Mystery Jack was played for the first time since 2018-11-24 (86 show gap). Ataraxia was on the written setlist but was replaced by Doom City. Following O.N.E. opening band Body Type was shouted out. The Dripping Tap featured a “flute jam” duet between Stu and Cecil Coleman of Body Type and contained Pill teases and Cellophane teases/quotes.

This was a fully acoustic show, the first one performed by the band outside of Australia. The River contained Wah Wah teases. Muddy Water featured Ambrose on sax. Cookie and Ambrose played on the same piano during Mr. Beat. Blame It On The Weather was introduced by Ambrose as a song about the weather in Melbourne, as well as being introduced as a song about Ambrose's dog by Stu. In the intro to The Bitter Boogie, which also featured Ambrose on sax, Joey says that the show is a "beta test" and asks if any of the crowd are going to Coachella, which the band played two days later. Dirt and Hot Water featured Mildlife guitarist Adam Halliwell on flute. Most Of What I Like also featured Ambrose on sax. The solo in Let Me Mend The Past was ommitted. Her and I featured Mildlife drummer Jim Rindfleish on congas and contained a Sleepwalker quote and tease and Crumbling Castle teases. KGLW.net Staff Notes: The setlist for this show is believed to be complete, but only partial recordings exist. All songs listed were confirmed through audio/video recordings, however The River through Muddy Water and Most Of What I Like are only partially available so any additional setlist notations that require audio confirmation (guest appearances, segues, quotes or teases) may be incomplete. If anyone has any further information or, ideally, a complete or conclusive recording please contact KGLW.net staff at setlists@kglw.net.

It was announced prior to the show that Stu was late to the stage because he had “diarrhea or something”. Stu then entered the stage costumed as “Disco Stu” and noted that it was his birthday show. After Hell, Stu teased "Stayin' Alive" (Bee Gees). Persistence was stopped partway through for a cake “being fucked by a sexy alien” to be presented to Stu, and for the crowd and band to sing “Happy Birthday to You” to Stu, after which Stu passed out the cake to the audience and several jokes were made about the cake's contents. Persistence was finished after the mid-song break. The River contained Wah Wah teases and an Ice V tease. Leah Senior was shouted out before Lava. At the end of the show, Stu was hit with silly string by the band while the audience sang to him again. KGLW.net Staff Notes: Fans of stage banter will want to listen to this show for humorous birthday comments throughout the show, and other amusing banter about being drunk and the Satanic nuns that often appear at their shows. After an instrumental intro to Am I in Heaven?, Stu, Joey, and Amby discuss recent dreams before continuing with the song. The song itself contained a “Stairway to Heaven” (Led Zeppelin) quote as well as “Stiff Upper Lip” (AC/DC) and Rattlesnake teases. Poster By Drew Millward

The Dripping Tap contained Cellophane teases. The River contained Iron Lung teases. Trapdoor was listed on the printed setlist after Muddy Water but was not played. Poster By Carlo Vivary

data.jamchart_notes: A behemoth of a version finds itself placed in the middle of one of the most playful sets the band has ever performed. From the get go the band is tight and energized featuring communicative interplay from all members. After moving through the composed section with aplomb, the main jam segment progresses in a manner similar to many electric renditions, ebbing and flowing through many ideas and themes, before cooling down and segueing into Wah Wah.
data.shownotes: This was a fully acoustic show (except for the electric bass), the fourth such show in the band’s history ( December 13, 2021, December 19, 2021, April 13, 2022). Scheduled opening band Kamikaze Palm Tree’s set was cancelled due to an inclement weather warning. Lonely Steel Sheet Flyer was played for the first time since May 8, 2022 (81 show gap). Muddy Water featured Amby on sax. The River (#1) contained Wah Wah teases. Wah Wah was unfinished. The River (#2) contained Wah Wah and Ice V teases. Amby dedicated Let Me Mend The Past, which contained an It Ain't Me, Babe (Bob Dylan) quote, to his father, Broderick Smith, who passed away recently. Following The Bitter Boogie, the band teased “Stairway to Heaven” (Led Zeppelin) and improvised a short bluegrass tune. Following The Wheel Stu briefly left the stage; while awaiting his return Joey quoted Superbad, stating he felt like Steven Glansburg and then teased “Taylor” (Jack Johnson), Amby quoted “Beyond the Sea” (Bobby Darin) and Joey teased and quoted “Are You Gonna Be My Girl” (Jet). Presumptuous featured Stu going around to every band member and giving them a sip of champagne, as well as spraying champagne on the crowd. Most Of What I Like was played for the first time since June 1, 2022 (70 show gap) and was dedicated by Joey to his partner Edith (Amby’s sister), had Stu and Amby sitting on piano together, and contained “Praise You” (Fatboy Slim) quotes/teases. Her and I contained teases of Am I In Heaven?, “España cañí” (Pascual Marquina Narro) and Blindness (The Fall). Slow Jam 1 and Sense were on the written setlist as the final 2 songs but were not played. KGLW.net Staff Notes: Fans of stage banter should check out this show, as the band, especially Stu, was in a talkative mood. Discussions included the band’s ability to chill hard, how acoustic nights are like days off for Cavs to drink, and even theorizing why Stu might be more talkative tonight. Poster By Jason Galea 485 Standard / 150 Foil Prints

data.jamchart_notes: Upon returning to The River, the band speeds up and moves through an ominous passage before everyone drops out other than Joey. Stu comes in with an anthemic progression to which Cavs and Amby contribute nicely. This resolves into the third section, the ending of which features some nice Wah Wah teasing from Joey and a dramatic transition into the outro. A groovy and funky rendition of the outro provides a nice capper to a rendition of the River of epic proportions.
data.shownotes: This was a fully acoustic show (except for the electric bass), the fourth such show in the band’s history ( December 13, 2021, December 19, 2021, April 13, 2022). Scheduled opening band Kamikaze Palm Tree’s set was cancelled due to an inclement weather warning. Lonely Steel Sheet Flyer was played for the first time since May 8, 2022 (81 show gap). Muddy Water featured Amby on sax. The River (#1) contained Wah Wah teases. Wah Wah was unfinished. The River (#2) contained Wah Wah and Ice V teases. Amby dedicated Let Me Mend The Past, which contained an It Ain't Me, Babe (Bob Dylan) quote, to his father, Broderick Smith, who passed away recently. Following The Bitter Boogie, the band teased “Stairway to Heaven” (Led Zeppelin) and improvised a short bluegrass tune. Following The Wheel Stu briefly left the stage; while awaiting his return Joey quoted Superbad, stating he felt like Steven Glansburg and then teased “Taylor” (Jack Johnson), Amby quoted “Beyond the Sea” (Bobby Darin) and Joey teased and quoted “Are You Gonna Be My Girl” (Jet). Presumptuous featured Stu going around to every band member and giving them a sip of champagne, as well as spraying champagne on the crowd. Most Of What I Like was played for the first time since June 1, 2022 (70 show gap) and was dedicated by Joey to his partner Edith (Amby’s sister), had Stu and Amby sitting on piano together, and contained “Praise You” (Fatboy Slim) quotes/teases. Her and I contained teases of Am I In Heaven?, “España cañí” (Pascual Marquina Narro) and Blindness (The Fall). Slow Jam 1 and Sense were on the written setlist as the final 2 songs but were not played. KGLW.net Staff Notes: Fans of stage banter should check out this show, as the band, especially Stu, was in a talkative mood. Discussions included the band’s ability to chill hard, how acoustic nights are like days off for Cavs to drink, and even theorizing why Stu might be more talkative tonight. Poster By Jason Galea 485 Standard / 150 Foil Prints

data.jamchart_notes: Referred to by fans as the ‘Dead River’
data.shownotes: An audience member named Seb was brought onstage to do the vocal intro to Nuclear Fusion, which contained a Hell's Itch tease. Joey shouted out Dead & Co. after Minimum Brain Size. Gaia was dedicated to John Mayer ("the guitar slayer"). The River contained a Wah Wah tease. Boogieman Sam contained “Got My Mojo Working” (Ann Cole), “Sweet Home Chicago” (Robert Johnson), “My Babe” (Little Walter), Cut Throat Boogie, and “Going Up the Country” (Canned Heat) quotes, “On the Road Again” (Canned Heat), Le Risque, and Head On/Pill teases, and The Dripping Tap teases/quotes. This show was released through the Official Bootlegger program as part of Live in Chicago '23. Poster By Jason Galea 460 Standard / 130 Foil

Anoxia was played for the first time since October 18, 2022 (52 show gap). Her and I contained Magenta Mountain and Blindness (The Fall) teases. After the song, Ambrose quotes Walk The Dinosaur (Was (Not Was)). Evil Death Roll contained Witchcraft and Converge teases. Wah Wah contained The River quotes. Only Parts I, II, and III of The River were performer and they contained Her and I (Slow Jam 2), Am I In Heaven?, and Hell's Itch teases. Float Along - Fill Your Lungs contained a Dragon jam. Poster By Jason Galea 420 Standard / 120 Foil

Anoxia was played for the first time since October 18, 2022 (52 show gap). Her and I contained Magenta Mountain and Blindness (The Fall) teases. After the song, Ambrose quotes Walk The Dinosaur (Was (Not Was)). Evil Death Roll contained Witchcraft and Converge teases. Wah Wah contained The River quotes. Only Parts I, II, and III of The River were performer and they contained Her and I (Slow Jam 2), Am I In Heaven?, and Hell's Itch teases. Float Along - Fill Your Lungs contained a Dragon jam. Poster By Jason Galea 420 Standard / 120 Foil

Float Along - Fill Your Lungs contained alternate lyrics and a Dragon jam. Lonely Steel Sheet Flyer contained an Ice V jam with lyrics. The River contained Ice V teases. Sleep Drifter contained Rattlesnake teases, Am I In Heaven? teases, and Billabong Valley quotes/teases. The vocal intro to Nuclear Fusion was done by an audience member named Lars who was brought on stage. Cavs teased Metallica’s One when Lars introduced himself. Straws In The Wind was humorously dedicated to everyone under 3 years old, as Joey had spotted multiple babies in the crowd and contained Extinction quotes.  Gaia contained a drum solo by Cavs.

The Dripping Tap contained a The River jam with an Ice V tease. The River contained Hell's Itch teases and Wah Wah quotes/teases. Wah Wah contained The River quotes & teases. Hot Water had lyrics changed to Time to Party and contained "Everybody Needs Somebody To Love” (Solomon Burke) quotes. Gaia was unfinished. KGLW.net Staff Notes: The first tease in The River could be noted as a tease of Hell’s Itch or Chang’e, as the riffs in both songs are basically identical. It was decided that since there is no indication of what the band’s intent was, the main difference is the instrument the riff is played on. Since the riff is played on guitar in Hell's Itch and keyboard/synth in Chang'e, with the tease in question being played on guitar, it was noted as a tease of Hell's Itch. It is ruled out as the also nearly identical Witchcraft/Flamethrower riff as those songs are in minor keys, while Hell's Itch/Chang'e are in major keys and match how the tease was played in this instance.

Hot Water had lyrics changed to Time to Party and contained "Everybody Needs Somebody To Love” (Solomon Burke) quotes. Gaia was unfinished. KGLW.net Staff Notes: The first tease in The River could be noted as a tease of Hell’s Itch or Chang’e, as the riffs in both songs are basically identical. It was decided that since there is no indication of what the band’s intent was, the main difference is the instrument the riff is played on. Since the riff is played on guitar in Hell's Itch and keyboard/synth in Chang'e, with the tease in question being played on guitar, it was noted as a tease of Hell's Itch. It is ruled out as the also nearly identical Witchcraft/Flamethrower riff as those songs are in minor keys, while Hell's Itch/Chang'e are in major keys and match how the tease was played in this instance.

KGLW.net Staff Notes: The setlist for this show is believed to be complete. Hot Water, The River, Astroturf, Minimum Brain Size and Dragon have been confirmed via audio/video recordings. The remaining songs were confirmed via the written setlist for the show and contemporaneous discussions through various social media, but any additional setlist notations that require audio confirmation (guest appearances, segues, quotes or teases) may be incomplete. If anyone has any further information or, ideally, a complete or conclusive recording please contact KGLW.net staff at setlists@kglw.net. Poster by Arno Kiss

This was King Gizzard's first show in South America. Head On/Pill contained Robot Stop teases and Am I In Heaven? teases & quotes.  Robot Stop contained Hot Water teases & quotes.  Venusian 2 contained Converge quotes.

This show featured a new synth table setup and the debuts of Extinction and Gondii. Grace Cummings unfortunately missed a second show due to illness, and was replaced with local Berlin artist Cosey Mueller. Extinction contained a Gondii tease and Flamethrower quotes. Gondii contained Extinction teases and quotes. The Dripping Tap contained Sad Pilot teases, Motor Spirit quotes, and a Witchcraft tease. Only Parts I, II, and III of The River were performed and they contained a Motor Spirit tease, Wah Wah teases and quotes, and Extinction teases. Wah Wah contained The River teases and Extinction teases and quotes. Let Me Mend The Past contained an It Ain't Me, Babe (Bob Dylan) quote. Before Gila Monster, the band thanks crew members Nico and Laura for building the new synth table setup at which point Cookie teases Happy Birthday. Gila Monster contained a Dragon tease. All Is Known and Rattlesnake were on the physical setlist (before and after Doom City respectively), but were cut for time. Poster by Amy Jean; Edition of 100

This show featured the debut of Daily Blues. Grace Cummings unfortunately missed a third show due to illness, and was replaced with Naarm synth-punk band Dr Sure's Unusual Practice. Crumbling Castle contained a Witchcraft tease. The Fourth Colour contained a Daily Blues jam with lyrics. Rattlesnake contained an intro jam while Ambrose ran offstage. The jam contained Sleep Drifter, Honey, and Straws In The Wind teases and the song itself contained teases of Honey, “Whole Lotta Rosie” (AC/DC) and Sleep Drifter. Wah Wah contained a The River intro. Only Part I, II, and III of The River were performed and they contained a Sad Pilot tease and Wah Wah teases and quotes. The Bitter Boogie was played with the drum pattern from Muddy Water. Poster by Amy Jean; Edition of 150

Grace Cummings returned from illness as the opening act. Float Along - Fill Your Lungs contained a Dragon jam with lyrics. Boogieman Sam contained a Sad Pilot jam with lyrics, "Midnight Rambler" (The Rolling Stones) quotes, and “Boogie” (Carson) teases and quotes. The Dripping Tap was dedicated to "everyone with diarrhea" and contained a You Can Be Your Sillouhette jam and Mycelium quotes. The Wheel was dedicated to David, the band's bus driver. This Thing contained an “Incredible” (M Beat) quote. Self-Immolate contained a drum solo. Following Converge, Joey shouted out opener Grace Cummings. Witchcraft was on the printed setlist after Converge, but was skipped. Poster by Amy Jean; Edition of 100

Grace Cummings returned from illness as the opening act. Float Along - Fill Your Lungs contained a Dragon jam with lyrics. Boogieman Sam contained a Sad Pilot jam with lyrics, "Midnight Rambler" (The Rolling Stones) quotes, and “Boogie” (Carson) teases and quotes. The Dripping Tap was dedicated to "everyone with diarrhea" and contained a You Can Be Your Sillouhette jam and Mycelium quotes. The Wheel was dedicated to David, the band's bus driver. This Thing contained an “Incredible” (M Beat) quote. Self-Immolate contained a drum solo. Following Converge, Joey shouted out opener Grace Cummings. Witchcraft was on the printed setlist after Converge, but was skipped. Poster by Amy Jean; Edition of 100

The entire band sat in with Grace Cummings for her song "Heaven". Joey thanked Grace before the show started, and Stu mentioned that they let the crew write the setlist. Before Danger $$$, Stu mentioned Gaspard requested the song. Wah Wah contained a The River intro. Only Part I, II, and III of The River was performed and they contained Wah Wah quotes with the "wah wah" refrain changed to "boogie boogie". Road Train was requested by Andrea. Mirage City was played for Jason Galea and was played electric for the first time. Before Sad Pilot, they dedicated the song to Sammy and talked about him recording and playing pedal steel on the new album. Work This Time was dedicated to Grace Cummings. The Dripping Tap was played for Maclay Heriot and contained a Motor Spirit jam, The Silver Cord teases, and Sea of Trees teases. The intro jam to Sleep Drifter contained O.N.E, Sleep Drifter, and Honey teases. Honey contained O.N.E, If Not Now, Then When?, and Billabong Valley teases. Ambrose quoted Ain’t No Mountain High Enough (Marvin Gaye & Tammi Terrell) before Billabong Valley. Before Motor Spirit, Stu asked the crowd who was throwing dinosaurs on stage, and Ambrose quoted Deserted Dunes Welcome Weary Feet. Motor Spirit was played for Jess Lewis because "it sounds like Tool". After Dragon, the band discussed playing Am I In Heaven? but pivoted to Self-Immolate.

This show featured the debut of Antarctica. The Dripping Tap contained Chang'e teases, You Can Be Your Silhouette teases, Antarctica teases & quotes, and Am I In Heaven? teases. Evil Death Roll was introduced as a song about Bob Dylan and contained Witchcraft and Robot Stop teases. Ice V contained a Witchcraft tease and a "Blindness" (The Fall) jam. The Fourth Colour, which was incomplete, contained a Daily Blues jam with lyrics and "Whole Lotta Rosie" (AC/DC) teases. Supercell was introduced as a song about orange juice. Following Motor Spirit, Joey introduced the band members. Gaia contained a jam with Joey on bass, which contained a Motor Spirit tease and a drum solo.

Poster by Jason Galea
Standard Edition of 650
Holographic Edition of 200

This show featured the debut of Gilgamesh. After Doom City, Ambrose shouted out opener Geese. East West Link was played for the first time since 2023-03-16 (78 show gap). Cavs teased Rock and Roll (Led Zeppelin) before Daily Blues and Stu said, "This song is about loving your enemy." Ambrose changed lyrics in Daily Blues to shout of the city of Philadelphia. Hot Water contained Antarctica, Float Along - Fill Your Lungs, and Grow Wings and Fly... quotes, Head On/Pill teases, and Daily Blues teases and quotes. Le Risque was introduced as "a little bit of ZZ Top" and followed an education by the band on Australian legend John Farnham. The River contained Gilgamesh quotes and Ice V teases. I'm Not In Your Mind contained a Motor Spirit and a The Land Before Timeland tease. Cellophane contained The Land Before Timeland teases. Gilgamesh contained a Set tease. Set contained Ice V teases and "I love you" lyrics from Stu. After the show, Ambrose said that night he was using a cheesesteak for a pillow. Poster by Jason Galea Standard Edition - 600 Foil Edition - 200

data.shownotes:
This show featured the debut of Hog Calling Contest. The first The Bitter Boogie contained the drums from Muddy Water and Muddy Water teases. Muddy Water contained the drums from The Bitter Boogie and The Bitter Boogie teases. The Bitter Boogie Reprise also contained a Muddy Water tease. Elbow was last played 2018-11-23. (257 show gap) After The River, which contained a Lost Woods (Koji Kondo) tease, the band wished Jay Weinberg a happy birthday. Le Risque and Gila Monster featured Jay Weinberg on drums. During Le Risque, Cavs went into the audience for his vocal part and asked an audience member (Devin) to do the "Let's Ride" lyric. Stressin’ was last played 2022-06-01. (141 show gap) Chang'e contained Witchcraft quotes. Extinction contained Gondii quotes.

Poster by Jason Galea
Standard - 1000
Gold Foil - 300

data.jamchart_notes: Acoustic. Despite only being Part I, it calmly stretches past 10 minutes. Contains in Motor Spirit and Theia teases before settling into a The Silver Cord vocal jam, with Theia quotes throughout.
data.shownotes: Chang'e contained Witchcraft quotes from the extended mix. Sense contained Witchcraft teases. Following Raw Feel, Cavs teased Hey Pachuco (Royal Crown Revue) from The Mask. Ambrose teased Flight b741 before Dirt. Following Dirt, Ambrose called Joey "Joe Dirt". Following Flight b741, Joey asked the crowd if anyone in the band had been to their 2022 show in San Diego (2022-04-11) and Stu asked if anyone had been to The Soda Bar (2016-05-18 and 2015-08-25), mentioning there was someone dressed in a panda suit there, who he then spotted in the crowd. Iron Lung contained Can't Stop (Red Hot Chili Peppers) and Witchcraft teases. Muddy Water contained The Bitter Boogie and The Castle In The Air teases. The Bitter Boogie contained the drums from Muddy Water as well as teases. After The Bitter Boogie, Joey teased Good Riddance (Green Day) and Every Morning (Sugar Ray) and asked Sammy to turn his mic through the PA, and Joey teased Every Morning and Good Riddance again. Ambrose then jokingly brought up Green Day’s infamous 2012 iHeartRadio incident (during which the band destroyed their instruments angrily after being told their set was being cut short) and multiple band members quoted Billie Joe Armstrong’s exclamations from the performance. God Is Calling Me Back Home had lyrics changed to "She's calling me back home" and featured Joey playing guitar with a beer bottle. Inbetween God Is Calling Me Back Home and Magma, Joey teased Tell Me Why (Neil Young). Magma was played for Sammy, featured an extended intro where the band shouted out their crew members, did not have the "rumble" verse, and contained a The Silver Cord jam with lyrics. After Magma, the band jokingly played a portion of Gaia acoustically. Theia contained Motor Spirit teases & quotes and The River teases. Only Part I of The River (which was introduced as a song about "when you wake up in the morning, and you smell something, in the kitchen, it’s not supposed to be there, and it smells real good, and you go eat it, and then you feel real good, then you feel real sick") was performed and it contained Motor Spirit teases, Theia teases, and a The Silver Cord vocal jam with Theia quotes. Honey and Pleura were on some of the written setlists following Horology but were replaced with Magma.
data.venuename: The Rady Shell at Jacobs Park

data.shownotes: Plastic Boogie contained Hypertension, The Land Before Timeland, The Dripping Tap, and This Thing teases. Straws In The Wind contained I’m Bored (Iggy Pop), Smoke & Mirrors, and Phantom Island quotes. Before Intrasport, the band introduced the synth table with its new nickname "Nathan". Set contained Ice V and Work This Time teases. Extinction contained the Flamethrower quotes from the extended mix. Irong Lung contained Hypertension teases. Hypertension contained a Crumbling Castle tease and a The Dripping Tap tease. Hog Calling Contest was teased before Antarctica, which contained Hot Water teases. Hog Calling Contest and Flight b741 featured Joey on acoustic guitar. The River contained Wah Wah teases and Row, Row, Row Your Boat (traditional) quotes.  Le Risque was on the written setlist after The River but was not played.

data.jamchart_notes: A nearly 23 minute version featuring chill jamming and a variety of teases.
data.shownotes: The Dripping Tap was unfinished. Rattlesnake contained Nuclear Fusion and Sleep Drifter teases. After Rattlesnake, Ambrose quoted an old Australian ad. Flamethrower featured a drum solo by Cavs. Extinction and Set featured the debut of the upgraded synth table (Nathan). Set contained Extinction quotes and Temporary Secretary (Paul McCartney) and The River teases. The River contained Thunderstruck (AC/DC) and Sad Pilot teases.

Altered Beast III, Alter Me III and Altered Beast IV were played for the first time since 2023-03-23 (115 shows).  Before Stressin', Stu teased Bullet in the Head (Rage Against The Machine). The Book was introduced a song about ancient stuff and featured a short drum solo. Hot Water was played in an alternate synth version for the first time. After Mirage City, Joey shouted out opener King Stingray and thanked guitarist Roy Kellaway for the Yothu Yindi shirt he was wearing. Robot Stop contained Hot Water and Crumbling Castle teases and Alter Me teases and quotes. Sea of Trees contained Hot Water and The Dripping Tap teases, Ice V teases, an Alter Me outro, and the second verse was changed to "I'm feeling kinda shit... but I've got my mates with me and I guess that is that, that’s that". Work This Time contained Mars For The Rich teases.

Show poster by Jason Galea - Edition of 100

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia
data.shownotes: This show featured the debut of Phantom Island, Deadstick, Lonely Cosmos, Eternal Return, Panpsych, Spacesick, Aerodynamic, Sea of Doubt, and Silent Spirit and was played with The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia conducted by Sarah Hicks. During Grow Wings and Fly, which contained Am I In Heaven? teases, Stu thanked the venue, The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia, and Sarah Hicks. The Dripping Tap contained Am I In Heaven? teases and was performed without The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia. Only parts I, II, and IV of The River were played. Crumbling Castle was played with the outro (without vocals) for the first time. The Dripping Tap was not on the printed setlist, but it and the jam following Grow Wings and Fly functioned as a setbreak for the orchestra.
data.soundcheck: The River, Crumbling Castle, Dragon, Iron Lung, This Thing, Mars For The Rich

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with The Orchestra of St. Luke’s
data.shownotes: This show was played with The Orchestra of St. Luke’s conducted by Sarah Hicks. During Grow Wings and Fly, Stu thanked The Orchestra of St. Luke’s and Sarah Hicks. Hot Water contained an Am I In Heaven? tease. Only parts I, II, and IV of The River were performed. Mars For The Rich was dedicated to the band's guitar tech Gaspard, who they then sung happy birthday to, followed by Stu asking the crowd if it was anyone else's birthday. Dragon was introduced as a song about "setting shit on fire". Following Dragon, Stu thanked The Orchestra of St. Luke’s and Sarah Hicks again and Ambrose thanked their tour manager Michelle.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with The Orchestra of St. Luke’s
data.shownotes: This show was played with The Orchestra of St. Luke’s conducted by Sarah Hicks. After Spacesick, Stu thanked The Orchestra of St. Luke’s and Sarah Hicks. Aerodynamic had a lyric changed to reference New York. After Sea of Doubt, Joey mentioned a wall of alumni backstage featuring acts who have previously performed at the venue, including the Beatles, Bob Dylan, Jimi Hendrix, and the Monkees, and the band expressed their desire to be added. During Grow Wings and Fly, Stu thanked The Orchestra of St. Luke’s and Sarah Hicks again. Magma, which didn't include the "rumble" section, contained Am I In Heaven?, The Dripping Tap, and Crumbling Castle teases and ended with a The River outro which contained Sad Pilot, Crumbling Castle, and Evil Death Roll teases. Only parts I, II, and IV of The River were performed. This Thing was introduced by Joey as a song about a personal secret, and included an Incredible (M-Beat) quote. Mars for the Rich was introduced as a song about Elon Musk, and included a lyric change to "you ain't coming here, the Tesla's too dear". After Mars for the Rich, the band noted that the two shows at this venue are the only two on this tour being livestreamed, wished someone a happy birthday, and exclaimed, "free Palestine motherfuckers!" After Iron Lung, the band thanked The Orchestra of St. Luke’s and Sarah Hicks one last time, as well as thanking the audience.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with The National Symphony Orchestra
data.shownotes: This show was played with The National Symphony Orchestra conducted by Sarah Hicks. During Grow Wings and Fly, Joey spoke about how even though Phantom Island talks about the band missing their families, the fans make it worth it. Following that, he said Free Palestine. Cut Throat Boogie featured a guitar/harmonica duel between Joey and Ambrose and was unfinished. Boogieman Sam contained Sad Pilot and Cut Throat Boogie teases. Only parts I, II, and IV of The River were performed. Before Dragon, the band mentioned Animal Collective's album Merriweather Post Pavilion, which was named after the venue.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with The Chicago Philharmonic
data.shownotes: This show was played with The Chicago Philharmonic conducted by Sarah Hicks. Panpsych's lyrics were changed to "Panpsych, fuck yeah". Silent Spirit contained a false start. Grow Wings and Fly contained additional lyrics about the band pissing themselves and a Theia jam with an Am I In Heaven? tease. Theia was performed in it's rock arrangement and contained Vomit Coffin and The Land Before Timeland teases, a Field of Vision jam, Sharp Dressed Man (ZZ Top) teases and quotes, and band introductions. Only parts I, II, and IV of The River were played. Following Crumbling Castle, Joey asked how the lawn was doing and said he couldn't see them (due to the venue layout making it hard to see the stage from the lawn). Stu then said he’d be in the lawn if he was watching. Mars For The Rich had lyrics changed to "Fuck Elon Musk" and "Tesla's too dear". Before Iron Lung, Ambrose thanked Chicago for hot dogs and the Blues Brothers, and Stu and Joey said Free Palestine.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with Colorado Symphony
data.shownotes: This show was played with The Colorado Symphony conducted by Sarah Hicks. Self-Immolate had Perihelion teases. Before The River Joey pointed out the full moon and mentioned Ozzy Osbourne. The band talked about Field of Vision and its Acid Yoga before Iron Lung.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with The Hollywood Bowl Orchestra
data.shownotes: This show was performed with The Hollywood Bowl Orchestra, conducted by Sarah Hicks. Grow Wings and Fly contained Plastic Boogie teases and a Hypertension jam with The Dripping Tap and Magma teases. At the start of the jam, Joey asked the pit what they were eating for dinner and said he hoped it wasn’t fish. Stu then joked that everyone had food poisoning before saying that it actually looked good. The band followed up by asking if the crowd had any desserts to share. A fan gave Cook tiramisu after he asked for it. He ate a bite and gave it back, and Stu joked that he put death cap mushrooms in it. Ambrose took a bucket of popcorn and ate it, later cleaning it off the stage after it went everywhere. This Thing was introduced by Joey as a song about Los Angeles, followed by him quoting I Love L.A. (Randy Newman). Mars for the Rich was dedicated to Elon Musk, with Stu saying the band decided all billionaires are going to prison (except Cook because he was chill) and had lyrics changed to “Tesla’s too dear” alongside an added “Free Palestine”. Ambrose gave a shout-out to his mom before Iron Lung. During the song, he walked into the garden pit and dumped a bucket of popcorn on himself.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with the San Diego Symphony Orchestra
data.shownotes: This show was played with The San Diego Symphony Orchestra conducted by Sarah Hicks. Sea of Doubt was introduced as "another one about the ocean." Grow Wings and Fly contained Motor Spirit, Wah Wah and Witchcraft teases. Before The River Stu received a tie-dye suit jacket from the audience. Mars For the Rich had lyric changed to "the Tesla's too dear" and was dedicated to David Bowie. Iron Lung contained Am I In Heaven? teases.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with Covent Garden Sinfonia
data.shownotes: This show was played with Covent Garden Sinfonia conducted by Chad Kelly. Before Phantom Island, the band said it was the best day of their lives and shouted out the orchestra and conductor Chad Kelly. After Eternal Return, Joey asked if anyone in the crowd was at the previous Brixton shows. Aerodynamic featured a lyric change to "watch the whole world go by". The Grow Wings and Fly jam had Hot Water, Head On/Pill and The Great Chain of Being teases. This Thing featured an Incredible (M Beat) quote. Mars For the Rich was introduced by Joey as a song about "how much of a massive fucking cunt" Elon Musk is and had a lyric change to "fuck Elon Musk!" Joey said "Free Palestine" after Dragon and Iron Lung.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with The Orchestre Lamoureux
data.shownotes: This show was played with The Orchestre Lamoureux conducted by Chad Kelly. After Eternal Return, Chad Kelly took a bathroom break, leading the band to do an impromptu jam. The Grow Wings and Fly jam had a Rattlesnake tease. This Thing was introduced as a song about Busy P.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with Sinfonia Rotterdam
data.shownotes: This show was played with Sinfonia Rotterdam conducted by Chad Kelly. Panpsych's lyrics were changed to "Panpsych, fuck yeah." Aerodynamic's lyrics were changed to "sit here and watch Max Verstappen float by." Following Silent Spirit, Joey dedicted Grow Wings and Fly to his daughter. Following Grow Wings and Fly, Joey shouted out conductor Chad Kelly and Amby shouted out Sinfonia Amsterdam (which Stu then corrected to Rotterdam).  the intermission jam contained an extensive The Land Before Timeland jam. Evil Death Roll contained a Robot Stop tease. The River contained Thunderstruck (AC/DC) teases. Following Crumbling Castle, which contained a The River tease, Joey shouted out Cavs. Mars For The Rich had lyrics changed to "Fuck Donald Trump" and "Tesla's too dear".

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with The Baltic Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra
data.shownotes: This show was played with The Baltic Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra conducted by Chad Kelly. The intermission jam featured Witchcraft teases and Motor Spirit quotes. The River also contained Motor Spirit quotes.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with Sydney Symphony Orchestra
data.shownotes: This show was played with The Sydney Symphony Orchestra conducted by Chad Kelly.  Intermission Jam contained Hypertension teases.  The River contained teases of Thunderstruck (AC/DC) and Her and I.  Dragon was introduced as a song about capitalism.  Before Iron Lung Joey said Free Palestine.

data.footnote: Parts I, II, and IV; with Sydney Symphony Orchestra
data.shownotes: This show was played with The Sydney Symphony Orchestra conducted by Chad Kelly. Before the band went on stage, they were introduced by Uncle Michael West during a freewheeling acknowledgement of country, fauna, and waterways. After Spacesick, Stu shouted out the orchestra and said how lucky they felt to play there, and Joey pointed out the audience could have gone to see Franz Ferdinand instead, who were performing that evening on the steps immediately outside the Sydney Opera House, but chose them; Aerodynamic then contained a lyric change to "just gonna sit here and watch Franz Ferdinand roll by". After Sea of Doubt, the band thanked Chad. Stu shouted out both the orchestra and Chad again at the end of Grow Wings and Fly. As the intermission jam started, Joey instructed the band to play more atonally as he related the story of playing the same venue when opening for The Drones on 2013-04-27, being unable to find a bathroom and choosing to urinate on that very stage. Daily Blues contained Green River teases. Jackson, one-half of the usual stream team and its only present member at this show, was shouted out after Daily Blues. Happy Birthday was performed by the orchestra for Lucas; afterwards Stu described him as one of his oldest friends and said he brought the band together. Crumbling Castle contained a lyric change to "thank you Gaspard", in reference to the band's guitar tech. Stu shouted out the orchestra and Chad after Crumbling Castle. Joey told another urination story before This Thing, which was then introduced as a song about that story. This Thing contained a lyric change to "and that is what makes this hard quiz" in reference to the Australian game show Hard Quiz, where the band was recently selected as a speciality topic by a fan Finn; who the band also joked about spotting in a small mosh pit that had formed at the end of an aisle on the venue floor. Before Mars for the Rich, Stu said "fuck Jeff Bezos" and repeatedly called for all billionaires to be sent to jail. The song itself contained a lyric change to "the Tesla's too dear". At the end, Ambrose said "thank you Sexy Alien". Dragon was dedicated to people who know about drop B and described as a song by Limp Bizkit; before the song started, Blind (Korn) was teased. At the end of the show, Chad and the orchestra were thanked again, along with Sam, Terrence and Jason.
This show was played with The Queensland Symphony Orchestra conducted by Chad Kelly.  Intermission Jam contained The Land Before Timeland teases.  Head On/Pill contained The Dripping Tap teases.

This show was played with The Queensland Symphony Orchestra conducted by Chad Kelly. The Intermission Jam contained Panpsych teases. Ice V contained Blindness (The Fall), Ain't It Funky Now (James Brown), The Land Before Timeland, Head On/Pill and Am I In Heaven? teases.
This show was played with Orchestra Victoria conducted by Chad Kelly. The Intermission Jam contained Daily Blues teases. Robot Stop contained The Dripping Tap and Hot Water teases.
